Timestamp of the requested image (in milliseconds since epoch).
The special value "latest", which is the default value, requires to retrieve the latest
thumbnail. The special value "now" requires to retrieve the thumbnail corresponding to
the current time.

Image orientation. Can be 0, 90, 180 or 270 degrees. If the
parameter is absent or equals -1, the image will be rotated as defined in the camera
settings.

Desired image height. Should be not less than 128, or equal to
-1 (the default value) which implies the original frame size, and in this case the width
should also be omitted or set to -1.

Desired image width. Should be not less than 128, or equal to -1
(the default value) which implies autosizing: if the height is specified, the width will
be calculated based on the aspect ratio, otherwise, the original frame size will be
used.
Format of the requested image. Default value is "JpgFormat".
PNG
JPEG
TIFF
Raw video frame. Makes the request much more lightweight for Edge servers.

Getting a thumbnail at the exact timestamp is costly, so, it
can be rounded to the nearest keyframe, thus, the default value is
"KeyFrameAfterMethod".
Get the thumbnail from the nearest keyframe before the given time.
Get the thumbnail as near to given time as possible.
Get the thumbnail from the nearest keyframe after the given time.

Allows to avoid scaling the image to the aspect ratio from
camera settings.
Default value. Use aspect ratio from camera settings (if any).
Use the source frame aspect ratio, despite the value in camera settings.

String containing a lower-case hex array of 21 bytes, which is a bit mask for a week (starting on Monday), where each consecutive bit corresponds to an hour and equals 1 for "enabled" and 0 for "disabled". Thus, the first byte describes the first 8 hours of Monday after midnight, and the last byte describes the last 8 hours of Sunday before midnight; in a byte, the highest significant bit corresponds to the earliest hour. description.xml: Return the recorded chunks info for the specified cameras.

Camera id (can be obtained from "id" field via /ec2/getCamerasEx or
/ec2/getCameras?extraFormatting) or MAC address (not supported for certain cameras).
This parameter can be used several times to define a list of cameras.
Start time of the interval (as a string containing time in milliseconds since epoch, or a local time formatted like "YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.zzz" - the format is auto-detected).
End time of the interval (as a string containing time in milliseconds since epoch, or a local time formatted like "YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.zzz" - the format is auto-detected).

This parameter is used for motion search ("periodsType" must be 1). Match motion on a video by specified rectangle.
Format: string with a JSON list of sensors, each sensor is a JSON list of rects, each rect is:
{"x": x, "y": y, "width": width,"height": height}
All values are measured in relative portions of a video frame, x and width in range [0..43], y and height in range [0..31], zero is the left-top corner.
Example of a full-frame rectangle for a single-sensor camera: [[{"x":0,"y":0,"width":43,"height":31}]]
Example of two rectangles for a single-sensor camera: [[{"x":0,"y":0,"width":5,"height":7},{"x":12,"y":10,"width":8,"height":6}]]
Data format. Default value is "json".
Universal Binary JSON data format.
JSON data format.
Internal comperssed binary format.

Chunk detail level, in microseconds. Time periods that are
shorter than the detail level are discarded. You can treat the detail level as the
amount of microseconds per screen pixel.
Chunk type.
All records.
Only chunks with motion (parameter "filter" is required).

If specified, standalone chunks smaller than the detail
level are not removed from the result.
Maximum number of chunks to return.
If specified, do not group chunk lists by server.

caption.xml:
JSON object with an error code, error message and the list of JSON objects in "reply" field: if no "flat" parameter is specified, "reply" field is the list which contains for each server its GUID (as "guid" field) and the list of chunks (as "periods" field); if "flat" parameter is specified, "reply" field is just the list of chunks.
Each chunk is a pair of (durationMs, startTimeMs). Chunks are merged for all requested cameras. Start time and duration are in milliseconds since epoch. Duration of -1 means the last chunk is being recorded now.

description.xml:
Using this method it is possible to trigger a generic event in the system from a 3rd party system. Such event will be handled and logged according to current event rules. Parameters of the generated event, such as "source", "caption" and "description", are intended to be analyzed by these rules.
Example:
This example triggers a generic event informing the system that a credit card has been used on September 16, 2016 at 16:03:41 UTC in a POS terminal being watched by the two specified cameras.

Event date and time (as a string containing time in milliseconds since epoch, or a local time formatted like "YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.zzz" - the format is auto-detected). If "timestamp" is absent, the current server date and time is used.

Name of the device which has triggered the event. It can be used
in a filter in event rules to assign different actions to different devices. Also, the
user could see this name in the notifications panel. Example: "POS terminal 5".

Short event description. It can be used in a filter in event
rules to assign actions depending on this text.

Long event description. It can be used as a filter in event
rules to assign actions depending on this text.

Additional information associated with the event, in the form of a JSON object. Currently this object can specify the only field "cameraRefs", but other fields could be added in the future.
  • "cameraRefs" specifies a number of cameras which are linked to the event (e.g. the event will appear on their timelines), in the form of a list of camera ids (can be obtained from "id" field via /ec2/getCamerasEx or /ec2/getCameras?extraFormatting).

Generic events can be used either with "long" actions like
"do recording", or instant actions like "send email". This parameter should be specified
in case "long" actions are going to be used with generic events.

Generic event is considered a "long" event. It transits to the "active"
state. "Long" actions will continue executing until the generic event transits to
the "inactive" state.

A "long" action associated with this generic event in event rules will
stop.

description.xml:
Merge two Systems.
The System that joins another System is called the current System, the joinable System is called the target System. The URL parameter sets the target Server which should be joined with the current System. Other servers, that are merged with the target Server will be joined if parameter mergeOneServer is set to false.
The method uses digest authentication. Two hashes should be previouly calculated: getKey and postKey. Both are mandatory. The calculation algorithm is described in Calculating authentication hash section (in the bootom of the page). While calculating hashes, username and password of the target Server are needed. Digest authentication needs realm and nonce, both can be obtained with GET /api/getNonce call call. The lifetime of a nonce is about a few minutes.
URL of one Server in the System to join.
Authentication hash of the target Server for GET requests.
Authentication hash of the target Server for POST requests.
Direction of the merge. Default value is false. If mergeOneServer is true, takeRemoteSettings parameter is ignored and treated as false.

The current system will get system name and administrator password of the
target system.

The target system will get system name and administrator password of the
current system.
Whether to merge with servers merged with the target server. Default value is false. If mergeOneServer is set to true, takeRemoteSettings is ignored and treated as false.

The current system will merge with target server only. The target server
will be disjoined from another system (if it was joined).

The current system will merge with target server and all servers which are
merged with the target server.

Whether to ignore different version of merged server
protocols. Default value is false.
Merge will start anyway.

If the target server protocol version differs from the current server
protocol version merge aborts.

groups.groupDescription: This group contains information about accessing cameras" live video and footage.

description.xml:
Open RTSP video stream from a camera.
                        It is not exactly an API method but rather a URL format which may contain
                        any camera id (can be obtained from "id" field via /ec2/getCamerasEx or /ec2/getCameras?extraFormatting) or MAC address (not
                        supported for certain cameras).
                        Example:
                        rtsp://<server_ip>:<port>/12AB42FD5912?pos=1235631&resolution=240p

By default, the server opens a camera at the live position. This parameter defines position in an archive (as a string containing time in milliseconds since epoch, or a local time formatted like "YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.zzz" - the format is auto-detected). Position can be passed via standard RTSP attribute as well as via URL parameter

Turn on video transcoding to the specified resolution. Resolution string either may contain width and height (for instance 320x240) or
                                                        height only (for instance 240p)

Rotate item. Can be 0, 90, 180 or 270 degrees. If the parameter is absent, video will be rotated to default value defined in a camera settings dialog.
                                         Parameter take place if video transcoding is activated (parameter codec and/or parameter resolution are presents.)
Defines video codec used for transcoding. Default value is H263.
H263 plus format
Motion JPEG
MPEG-4 part 2
VP8 video codec

Open high quality stream if parameter is 0 or low quality stream if parameter is 1.
                                         By default server auto detect preferred stream index based on destination resolution.
Playback speed. Only values in range [1..32] are supported. Default value is 1.

caption.xml: RTSP video stream.

description.xml:
Open HTTP video stream from a camera.
                        It is not exactly an API method but rather a URL format which may contain
                        any camera id (can be obtained from "id" field via /ec2/getCamerasEx or /ec2/getCameras?extraFormatting) or MAC address (not
                        supported for certain cameras).
                        Codec and stream format can be specified in URL parameters. Live stream and
                        archive can be downloaded. If required and possible, media stream
                        transcoding is performed on-the-fly. Stream format can be one of the
                        following: webm, mpegts, mpjpeg (motion jpeg).
                        Example:
                        http://<server_ip>:<port>/media/12AB42FD5912.webm
Video stream resolution. Example: 720x576, 1920x1080, 720p, 1080p. By default, 640x480 is used

If present and not equal to <now>, specifies archive stream start position (as a string containing time in milliseconds since epoch, or a local time formatted like "YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.zzz" - the format is auto-detected). Otherwise, LIVE stream is provided

If present, specifies archive stream end position (as a string containing time in milliseconds since epoch, or a local time formatted like "YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.zzz" - the format is auto-detected). It is used only if "pos" parameter is present.
Rotate item. Can be 0, 90, 180 or 270 degrees. If the parameter is absent, video will be rotated to default value defined in a camera settings dialog.
Stand Frame Duration. If the parameter is present, video speed is limited by real time.
Turn on realtime optimization. It will drop some frames if not enough CPU for realtime transcoding.

caption.xml: Video stream in the requested format

description.xml:
Open HTTP Live Streaming (HLS) video stream from a camera.
                        It is not exactly an API method but rather a URL format which may contain
                        any camera id (can be obtained from "id" field via /ec2/getCamerasEx or /ec2/getCameras?extraFormatting) or MAC address (not
                        supported for certain cameras).
                        This protocol is supported by iOS-based devices (iPhone, iPad).
                        Example:
                        http://<server_ip>:<port>/hls/12AB42FD5912.m3u
Camera archive position to open (as a string containing time in milliseconds since epoch, or a local time formatted like "YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.zzz" - the format is auto-detected).

If specified, only hi quality is available on streaming session. If neither <hi> nor <lo> is specified than HLS client is allowed to perform dynamic stream switching (to fit in available bandwidth and compensate for traffic congestion)

If specified, only low quality is available on streaming session. If neither <hi> nor <lo> is specified than HLS client is allowed to perform dynamic stream switching (to fit in available bandwidth and compensate for traffic congestion)

caption.xml: Video stream in mpeg-2/ts format

description.xml:
Download fragment of a camera archive, identified by its start time and
                        duration.
                        It is not exactly an API method but rather a URL format which may contain
                        any camera id (can be obtained from "id" field via /ec2/getCamerasEx or /ec2/getCameras?extraFormatting) or MAC address (not
                        supported for certain cameras).
                        Fragment can be downloaded in mpeg-2/ts (.ts) or Matroska (.mkv) format.

Fragment start time (as a string containing time in milliseconds since epoch, or a local time formatted like "YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.zzz" - the format is auto-detected).

caption.xml: Result of the target API request.

groups.groupDescription: Request authentication methods supported by server.

description.xml:
This method is preferable for external applications, most of HTTP libraries support it.
Server is fully conformant with the authentication defined in rfc2617 (https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2617).

This method should only be used in browser javascript applications.
Cookie authorization scheme allows to avoid standard login/password dialog in web-applications.
It provides you a way to replace it with your own dialog.
It works mostly like sessions, but is a bit more secure because it doesn't send user's password over HTTP.
  • To check authentication:
    1. Call GET /api/getCurrentUser
    2. You will get 401 (Unauthorised) in case you need authorization
    3. You will get 200 (OK) and the user object otherwise
  • To log in:
    1. Call GET /api/getNonce
    2. In response you'll get a JSON object with realm and nonce (nonce is a session key for this user)
    3. Calculate authentication hash auth_digest, using realm and nonce (see algorithm below)
    4. Call POST /api/cookieLogin and pass the "auth" parameter in the json request body
    5. Server will check authentication and set session cookies
  • Executing requests:
    1. Session cookie should be supplied with every request, browser does it automatically if cookies are enabled
    2. HTTP header Nx-Vms-Csrf-Token should contain the key from nx-vms-csrf-token cookie value
  • To log out:
    1. Call POST /api/cookieLogout
    2. Server will clear the session cookies

This method should only be used if other methods are not applicable, e.g. webm direct link.
Add the "auth" parameter to the URL query section of any GET request
  • Call /api/getNonce to get realm and nonce from the server (the current server time is used as a nonce value, and the nonce is valid for about 5 minutes)
  • Calculate the authentication hash auth_digest, using realm and nonce (see algorithm below)
  • Specify the authentication hash in the URL parameter: http://127.0.0.1:7001/method?auth=auth_digest&other_params

For URL-based authentication and cookie-based authentication you need to calculate the hash manually, using the following algorithm:
  • Call GET /api/getNonce
  • In response you'll get a JSON object with realm and nonce
  • Translate user's username to the lower case
  • Check the required method ("GET" for HTTP GET requests, "POST" for HTTP POST requests, "PLAY" for RTSP etc)
  • digest = md5_hex(user_name + ":" + realm + ":" + password)
  • partial_ha2 = md5_hex(method + ":")
  • simplified_ha2 = md5_hex(digest + ":" + nonce + ":" + partial_ha2)
  • auth_digest = base64(user_name + ":" + nonce + ":" + simplified_ha2)
  • Here auth_digest is the required authentication hash
